history.narrative: Law 14-213, the “Technical Amendments Act of 2002”, was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 14-671, which was referred to the Committee of the Whole. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on June 4, 2002, and July 2, 2002, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on July 26, 2002, it was assigned Act No. 14-459 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 14-213 became effective on October 19, 2002.

AN ACT IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA To amend the Advisory Neighborhood Commissions Boundaries Act of 2002 to correctly identify the boundaries, clarify boundary descriptions, conform the boundary descriptions to the 2002 ANC Boundary Maps, include omitted words, change the capitalization of a word, correct the name of certain streets, change a compass direction, correct a typographical error and correct punctuation; to amend the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978 to add definitions, to clarify job and procedural protections for employees in the Excepted Service, to repeal obsolete sections, to explain the classification policy and applicable factors for the determination of grade levels for the positions in the Career, Educational, Legal, and Excepted Services, to require that the Mayor provide for the development of a classification system covering all positions in the Career, Educational, Legal, and Excepted Services, to add the Management Supervisory Service to the services listed, to conform the language regarding entitlement to military leave to changes in federal law and regulations, and to correct a cross-reference; to amend the District of Columbia Campaign Finance Reform and Conflict of Interest Act to add Management Supervisory service employees at a grade level of 13 or above to those employees who are required to file a financial statement every year; to amend the District of Columbia Codification Act of 1975 to clarify the effective date of revenue bond resolutions; to amend the Minority Contracting Act of 1976 to amend an obsolete provision and to add a cross-reference to the Confirmation Act of 1978; to repeal the District of Columbia Economic Development Finance Corporation Act of 1984; to amend the National Capital Revitalization Corporation Act of 1998 to include a cross-reference to the Confirmation Act of 1978; to amend the Omnibus Sports Consolidation Act of 1994 to include a cross-reference to the Confirmation Act of 1978; to amend the District of Columbia Police and Firemen's Salary Act of 1958 to ensure that longevity pay is included in retirement calculations for all police officers who have retired since August 29, 1972; Official Code § 1-612.03) is amended as follows 1) Subsection (m) is amended to read as follows: “(m) An employee is entitled to leave without loss in pay, leave, service, or performance rating for active duty, inactive-duty training (as defined in 37 U.S.C. § 101 or to engage in field coast defense training under 32 U.S.C. §§ 502 through 505 as a reserve member of the armed forces or member of the National Guard. Leave under this subsection shall not exceed 15 calendar days per fiscal year and, to the extent that it is not used in a fiscal year, shall accumulate for use in the succeeding fiscal year until it totals 15 days at the beginning of a fiscal year. In the case of part-time employment, the rate at which leave accrues under this subsection shall be a percentage of the rate prescribed above which is determined by dividing 40 into the number of hours in the regularly scheduled workweek of that employee during that fiscal year. The minimum charge for leave under this subsection is one hour, and additional charges are in multiples thereof.” 2) New sections (m-1 m-2 and (m-3) are added to read as follows: “(m-1) An employee who is a member of a reserve component of the armed forces, as described in 10 U.S.C. § 10101, or the National Guard, as described in 32 U.S.C. § 101 and who performs, for the purpose of providing military aid to enforce the law or for the purpose of providing assistance to civil authorities in the protection or saving of life, property, or the Amend § 1-609.05 Amend § 1-610.59 Amend § 1-611.01 Amend § 1-611.01 Amend § 1-611.02 Amend § 1-611.03 Amend § 1-611.03 Amend § 1-611.04 Amend § 1-612.03 ENROLLED ORIGINAL 21Codification District of Columbia Official Code, 2001 Edition West Group Publisher, 1-800-228-2180. prevention of injury, under the following 1) Federal service under 10 U.S.C. §§ 331, 332, 333, or 12406 or other provision of law, as applicable, or 2) Full-time military service for his or her state, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, or a territory of the United States is entitled, during and because of such service, to leave without loss of, or reduction in, pay, leave to which he or her would be otherwise entitled, and credit for service or a performance rating. Leave granted by this paragraph shall not exceed 22 workdays in a calendar year. “(m-2) Upon the request of an employee, the period for which an employee is absent to perform service described by this subsection may be charged to the employee's accrued annual leave or to compensatory time available to the employee instead of being charged as leave to which the employee is entitled under this subsection. The period of absence may not be charged to sick leave. An employee who is a member of the National Guard of the District of Columbia is entitled to leave without limitation and without loss in pay or time for each day of a parade or encampment ordered or authorized under title 49 of the District of Columbia Official Code. This provision covers each day of service in the National Guard, or a portion thereof, that an employee is ordered to perform by the Commanding General. “(m-3) An amount (other than travel, transportation, or per diem allowance) received by an employee for military service as a member of the reserve or National Guard for a period for which he or she is entitled to military leave shall be credited against the pay payable to the employee for the same period.” l) Section 1801(a-1 D.C.
